translated: the four Bases of Success, the four Ways of Attending to Mindfulness, the four Jhanas, the four Immeasurables.

original: Tattha ye dukkhāya paṭipadāya dandhābhiññāya khippābhiññāya ca niyyanti ime dve puggalā.
analyzed: tattha ye dukkhāya paṭipadāya dandha abhiññāya khippa abhiññāya ca niyyanti ime dve puggalā
translated: Herein, those who go forth by the painful way with slow deep knowledge and with swift deep knowledge are two persons.

original: Ye sukhāya paṭipadāya dandhābhiññāya khippābhiññāya ca niyyanti, ime dve puggalā.
analyzed: ye sukhāya paṭipadāya dandha abhiññāya khippa abhiññāya ca niyyanti ime dve puggalā
translated: Those who go forth by the pleasant way with slow deep knowledge and with swift deep knowledge are two persons.

original: Tattha yo sukhāya paṭipadāya khippābhiññāya niyyāti, ayaṁ ugghaṭitaññū.
analyzed: tattha yaḥ sukhāya paṭipadāya khippa abhiññāya niyyāti ayam ugghaṭita ññū
translated: Herein, he who goes forth by the pleasant way with swift deep knowledge is the type who is responsive to brief instructions.

original: Yo sādhāraṇāya, ayaṁ vipañcitaññū.
analyzed: sādhāraṇāya ayam
translated: He who goes forth by the way shared in common is the type who is responsive to detailed instructions.

original: Yo dukkhāya paṭipadāya dandhābhiññāya niyyāti, ayaṁ neyyo.
analyzed: yaḥ dukkhāya paṭipadāya dandha abhiññāya niyyāti ayam neyyaḥ
translated: He who goes forth by the painful way with slow deep knowledge is the type who is guidable.

original: Tattha bhagavā ugghaṭitaññussa puggalassa samathaṁ upadisati, neyyassa vipassanaṁ, samathavipassanaṁ vipañcitaññussa.
analyzed: tattha bhagavā ugghaṭitaññussa puggalassa samatham upadisati neyyassa vipassana samatha vipassanam vipañcitaññussa
translated: Herein, the Blessed One teaches serenity to the person who is responsive to brief instructions, insight to the person who is guidable, and both serenity and insight to the person who is responsive to detailed instructions.

original: Tattha bhagavā ugghaṭitaññussa puggalassa mudukaṁ dhammadesanaṁ upadisati, tikkhaṁ
analyzed: tattha bhagavā ugghaṭita ññussa puggalassa mudukam dhamma desanam upadisati tikkha
translated: Herein, the Blessed One teaches the Dhamma in a mild way to the person of quick understanding, and in an intensive way to the person of slow understanding.

original: neyyassa, mudutikkhaṁ vipañcitaññussa, tattha bhagavā ugghaṭitaññussa puggalassa🔽saṅkhittena dhammaṁ desayati, saṅkhittavitthārena vipañcitaññussa, vitthārena neyyassa.🔽Tattha bhagavā ugghaṭitaññussa puggalassa nissaraṇaṁ upadisati, vipañcitaññussa ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca upadisati, neyyassa assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca upadisati.
analyzed: neyyassa mudutikkham tattha bhagavā ugghaṭita ññussa puggalassa  saṅkhittena dhammam desayati saṅkhitta vitthārena vipañcitaññussa vitthārena neyyassa  tattha bhagavā ugghaṭita aññussa puggalassa nissaraṇam upadisati vipañcita aññussa ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca upadisati neyyassa assādam ca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca upadisati
translated: Herein, the Blessed One teaches the gentle kind of Dhamma teaching to the person of the type ready-to-be-sensed, the sharp kind to the person of the type to be led , and the gentle-and-sharp kind to the person of the type ready-to-be-analysed.🔽Herein, the Blessed One teaches the Dhamma in brief to the person of the type ready-to-be-sensed, in brief and in detail to the person of the type ready-to-be-analysed, and in detail to the person of the type to be led.🔽Herein, the Blessed One teaches the escape to the person of the type ready-to-be-sensed, and he teaches both the danger and the escape to the person of the type ready-to-be-analysed, and he teaches both the bait and the danger and the escape to the person of the type to be led.

original: Tattha bhagavā ugghaṭitaññussa adhipaññāsikkhaṁ paññāpayati, adhicittaṁ vipañcitaññussa, adhisīlaṁ neyyassa.🔽Tattha ye dukkhāya paṭipadāya dandhābhiññāya khippābhiññāya ca niyyanti, ime dve puggalā.
analyzed: tattha bhagavā ugghaṭitaññussa adhi paññā sikkham paññāpayati adhicittam vipañcitaññussa adhisīlam neyyassa  tattha ye dukkhāya paṭipadāya dandha abhiññāya khippa abhiññāya ca niyyanti ime dve puggalā
translated: Herein, the Blessed One makes the training in higher understanding paramount for the person of the type ready-to-be-sensed, the training in higher cognizance for the person of the type ready-to-be-analysed, and the training in higher virtue for the person of the type to be led.🔽Herein, those who go forth by the painful way with slow and swift direct-knowledge are the two persons.

original: Ye sukhāya paṭipadāya dandhābhiññāya khippābhiññāya ca niyyanti.
analyzed: ye sukhāya paṭipadāya dandha abhiññāya khippa abhiññāya ca niyyanti
translated: Those who go forth by the pleasant way with slow and swift direct-knowledge are the two persons.

original: Ime dve puggalā.🔽Iti kho cattāri hutvā tīṇi bhavanti ugghaṭitaññū vipañcitaññū neyyoti.
analyzed: ime dve puggalā  iti kho cattāri hutvā tīṇi bhavanti ugghaṭita ññū vipañcita ññū
translated: These are the two kinds of people.🔽So it is that, having been four, they become three: the person with quick understanding who has faith, the person with quick understanding who has faith and is devoted to the Dhamma, and the person with slow understanding who has faith and is devoted to the Dhamma.🔽These are the three kinds of people.

original: Tesaṁ tiṇṇaṁ puggalānaṁ ayaṁ saṅkileso, tīṇi akusalamūlāni lobho akusalamūlaṁ doso akusalamūlaṁ moho akusalamūlaṁ, tīṇi duccaritāni—🔽kāyaduccaritaṁ vacīduccaritaṁ manoduccaritaṁ;
analyzed: tesam tiṇṇam puggalānam ayam saṅkilesaḥ tīṇi akusala mūlāni lobhaḥ akusala mūlam dosaḥ akusala mūlam mohaḥ tīṇi duccaritāni  kāya duccaritam vacī duccaritam manaḥ duccarita
translated: These are the three kinds of defilements: greed, hatred, and delusion.🔽These are the three kinds of misconduct: misconduct by body, speech, and mind.

original: tayo akusalavitakkā—
analyzed: tayaḥ akusala vitakkā
translated: These are the three kinds of unwholesome thoughts:

original: kāmavitakko byāpādavitakko vihiṁsāvitakko;
analyzed: kāma vitakkaḥ byāpāda vitakkaḥ vihisā vitakkaḥ
translated: thoughts of sensuality, thoughts of ill will, and thoughts of harming.

original: tisso akusalasaññā—
analyzed: tissaḥ akusala saññā
translated: These are the three kinds of unwholesome perceptions:

original: kāmasaññā byāpādasaññā vihiṁsāsaññā;
analyzed: kāma saññā byāpāda saññā vihisā saññā
translated: perceptions of sensuality, perceptions of ill will, and perceptions of harming.

original: tisso viparītasaññā—
analyzed: tissaḥ viparīta saññā
translated: These are the three kinds of wrong perceptions:

original: niccasaññā sukhasaññā attasaññā;
analyzed: nicca saññā sukha saññā atta saññā
translated: perceptions of permanence, perceptions of pleasure, and perceptions of self.

original: tisso vedanā—
analyzed: tissaḥ vedanā
translated: These are the three kinds of feelings:

original: sukhā vedanā dukkhā vedanā adukkhamasukhā vedanā;
analyzed: sukhā vedanā dukkhā vedanā adukkhamasukhā vedanā
translated: pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant.

original: tisso dukkhatā—
analyzed: tissaḥ dukkha tā
translated: These are the three kinds of suffering:

original: dukkhadukkhatā saṅkhāradukkhatā vipariṇāmadukkhatā;
analyzed: dukkha dukkha tā saṅkhāra dukkha tā vipariṇāma dukkha tā
translated: suffering due to suffering, suffering due to formations, and suffering due to change.

original: tayo aggī—
analyzed: tayaḥ aggī
translated: These are the three fires:

original: rāgaggi dosaggi mohaggi;
analyzed: rāga aggi dosa aggi moha aggi
translated: the fire of sensuality, the fire of ill will, and the fire of confusion.

original: tayo sallā—
analyzed: tayoḥ sallā
translated: These are the three arrows:

original: rāgasallo dosasallo mohasallo;
analyzed: rāga sallaḥ dosa sallaḥ moha sallaḥ
translated: the arrow of sensuality, the arrow of ill will, and the arrow of confusion.

original: tisso jaṭā—
analyzed: tissaḥ jaṭā
translated: These are the three tangles:

original: rāgajaṭā dosajaṭā mohajaṭā;
translated: the tangle of sensuality, the tangle of ill will, and the tangle of confusion.

original: tisso akusalūpaparikkhā—
analyzed: tissaḥ akusala upaparikkhā
translated: There are three kinds of unwholesome investigation:

original: akusalaṁ kāyakammaṁ akusalaṁ vacīkammaṁ akusalaṁ manokammaṁ.
analyzed: akusalam kāya kammam akusalam vacī kammam akusalam manaḥ kamma
translated: unwholesome bodily action, unwholesome verbal action, and unwholesome mental action.

original: Tisso vipattiyo—
analyzed: tissaḥ vipattiyaḥ
translated: There are three kinds of failure:

original: sīlavipatti diṭṭhivipatti ācāravipattīti.🔽Tesaṁ tiṇṇaṁ puggalānaṁ idaṁ vodānaṁ.
analyzed: sīla vipatti diṭṭhi vipatti ācāra vipatti iti  tesam tiṇṇam puggalānam idam vodāna
translated: failure in morality, failure in view, and failure in conduct.🔽These are the three kinds of purification for those three kinds of people.

original: Tīṇi kusalamūlāni—
analyzed: tīṇi kusala mūlāni
translated: There are three wholesome roots:

original: alobho kusalamūlaṁ adoso kusalamūlaṁ amoho kusalamūlaṁ.
analyzed: a lobhaḥ kusala mūlam a dosaḥ kusala mūlam a mohaḥ kusala mūla
translated: non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion.

original: Tīṇi sucaritāni—
analyzed: tīṇi su caritāni
translated: There are three kinds of good conduct:

original: kāyasucaritaṁ vacīsucaritaṁ manosucaritaṁ.
analyzed: kāya su caritam vacī su caritam manaḥ su carita
translated: good bodily conduct, good verbal conduct, and good mental conduct.

original: Tayo kusalavitakkā—
analyzed: tayo kusala vitakkā
translated: There are three wholesome thoughts:

original: nekkhammavitakko abyāpādavitakko avihiṁsāvitakko.
analyzed: nekkhamma vitakko a byāpāda vitakko a vihisā vitakko
translated: thoughts of renunciation, thoughts of non-ill will, and thoughts of non-cruelty.

original: Tayo samādhī—
analyzed: tayoḥ samādhī
translated: There are three kinds of concentration:

original: savitakko savicāro samādhi avitakko vicāramatto samādhi avitakko avicāro samādhi.
analyzed: sa vitakkaḥ sa vicāraḥ samādhi a vitakkaḥ vicāra mattaḥ samādhi a vitakkaḥ a vicāraḥ samādhi
translated: concentration with thought and examination, concentration without thought but with examination, and concentration without thought and examination.

original: Tisso kusalasaññā—
analyzed: tissaḥ kusala saññā
translated: There are three wholesome perceptions:

original: nekkhammasaññā abyāpādasaññā avihiṁsāsaññā.
analyzed: nekkhamma saññā a byāpāda saññā a vihisā saññā
translated: the perception of renunciation, the perception of non-ill will, and the perception of non-cruelty.

original: Tisso aviparītasaññā—
analyzed: tissaḥ a viparīta saññā
translated: There are three unperverted perceptions:

original: aniccasaññā dukkhasaññā anattasaññā.
analyzed: anicca saññā dukkha saññā anatta saññā
translated: the perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering in impermanence, and the perception of non-self in suffering.

original: Tisso kusalūpaparikkhā—
analyzed: tissaḥ kusala upaparikkhā
translated: There are three kinds of wholesome investigation:

original: kusalaṁ kāyakammaṁ kusalaṁ vacīkammaṁ kusalaṁ manokammaṁ.
analyzed: kusalam kāya kammam kusalam vacī kammam kusalam manaḥ kamma
translated: wholesome bodily action, wholesome verbal action, and wholesome mental action.

original: Tīṇi soceyyāni—
analyzed: tīṇi soceyyāni
translated: There are three kinds of purity:

original: kāyasoceyyaṁ vacīsoceyyaṁ manosoceyyaṁ;
analyzed: kāya soceyyam vacī soceyyam manaḥ soceyya
translated: purity of body, purity of speech, purity of mind.

original: tisso sampattiyo—
analyzed: tissaḥ sampattiyaḥ
translated: There are three kinds of success:

original: sīlasampatti samādhisampatti paññāsampatti.
analyzed: sīla sampatti samādhi sampatti paññā sampatti
translated: success in virtue, success in concentration, success in wisdom.

original: Tisso sikkhā—
analyzed: tissaḥ sikkhā
translated: There are three trainings:

original: adhisīlasikkhā adhicittasikkhā adhipaññāsikkhā;
analyzed: adhi sīla sikkhā adhi citta sikkhā adhi paññā sikkhā
translated: the training in the higher virtue, the training in the higher mind, the training in the higher wisdom.

original: tayo khandhā—
analyzed: tayaḥ khandhā
translated: There are three categories:

original: sīlakkhandho samādhikkhandho paññākkhandho.
analyzed: sīla kkhandho samādhi kkhandho paññā kkhandho
translated: the category of virtue, the category of concentration, the category of wisdom.

original: Tīṇi vimokkhamukhāni—
analyzed: tīṇi vimokkha mukhāni
translated: There are three doors to liberation:

original: suññataṁ animittaṁ appaṇihitanti.
analyzed: suññatam animittam appaṇihitam ti
translated: emptiness, desirelessness, and signlessness.

original: Iti kho cattāri hutvā tīṇi bhavanti, tīṇi hutvā dve bhavanti taṇhācarito ca diṭṭhicarito ca.🔽Tesaṁ dvinnaṁ puggalānaṁ ayaṁ saṅkileso, taṇhā ca avijjā ca ahirikañca anottappañca🔽assati ca asampajaññañca ayoniso manasikāro ca kosajjañca dovacassañca ahaṅkāro ca
analyzed: iti kho cattāri hutvā tīṇi bhavanti tīṇi hutvā dve bhavanti taṇhā carito ca diṭṭhi carito ca  tesam dvinnam puggalānam ayam saṅkilesaḥ taṇhā ca avijjā ca ahirikam ca anottappam ca  assati ca asampajaññañca ayonisaḥ manasikāro ca kosajjañca dovacassañca ahaṅkāro ca
translated: So it is that, having been four, they become three; having been three, they become two: the one who is disposed to craving and the one who is disposed to views.🔽These are the defilements of these two kinds of persons: craving and ignorance, lack of shame and lack of fear of wrongdoing,🔽forgetfulness and lack of full awareness, unwise reflection and idleness, unfriendliness and self-inflation,

original: mamaṅkāro ca assaddhā ca pamādo ca asaddhammassavanañca asaṁvaro ca abhijjhā ca byāpādo
analyzed: mamaṅkāro ca assaddhā ca pamādaḥ ca asat dhamma ssavanañca asavaraḥ ca abhijjhā ca byāpādo
translated: self-identification and lack of faith and heedfulness, listening to Dhamma and lack of restraint, covetousness and ill will,

original: ca nīvaraṇañca saṁyojanañca kodho ca upanāho ca makkho ca palāso ca issā ca maccherañca
analyzed: ca nīvaraṇañca sayojanañca kodhaḥ ca upanāhaḥ ca makkhaḥ ca palāsaḥ ca issā ca maccherañca
translated: and the hindrances, and the fetters, and anger, and resentment, and contempt, and insolence, and envy, and avarice,

original: māyā ca sāṭheyyañca sassatadiṭṭhi ca ucchedadiṭṭhi cāti.🔽Tesaṁ dvinnaṁ puggalānaṁ idaṁ vodānaṁ, samatho ca vipassanā ca hirī ca ottappañca🔽sati ca sampajaññañca yoniso manasikāro ca vīriyārambho ca sovacassañca dhamme ñāṇañca
analyzed: māyā ca sāṭheyyam ca sassata diṭṭhi ca uccheda diṭṭhi ca ati  tesam dvinnam puggalānam idam vodāna samatho ca vipassanā ca hirī ca ottappañca  sati ca sampajaññañca yonisas manasikāro ca vīriya ārambho ca sovacassañca dhamme ñāṇañca
translated: and deceit, and fraud, and the view of eternity, and the view of annihilation.🔽For these two persons this is the purification, and calm and insight, and conscience, and shame,🔽and mindfulness, and clear comprehension, and wise attention, and the arousing of energy, and being easy to admonish, and knowledge of the Dhamma,

original: anvaye ñāṇañca khaye ñāṇañca anuppāde ñāṇañca saddhā ca appamādo ca saddhammassavanañca
analyzed: anvaye ñāṇañca khaye ñāṇañca anuppāde ñāṇañca saddhā ca appamādaḥ ca saddhamma ssavanañca
translated: and knowledge of the order, and knowledge of the right time, and knowledge of the proper measure, and knowledge of people, and faith, and diligence, and hearing the true Dhamma,

original: saṁvaro ca anabhijjhā ca abyāpādo ca rāgavirāgā ca cetovimutti avijjāvirāgā ca paññāvimutti
analyzed: savaraḥ ca anabhijjhā ca abyāpādaḥ ca rāga virāgā ca cetas vimutti avijjā virāgā ca paññā vimutti
translated: and restraint, and non-greed, and non-ill will, and the fading away of lust, and the fading away of ignorance, and the liberation of mind, and the liberation by wisdom,

original: abhisamayo ca appicchatā ca santuṭṭhi ca akkodho ca anupanāho ca amakkho ca apalāso
analyzed: abhisamayaḥ ca appiccha tā ca santuṭṭhi ca akkodhaḥ ca anupanāhaḥ ca amakkhaḥ ca apalāso
translated: and penetration, and fewness of wishes, and contentment, and non-anger, and non-resentment, and non-contempt, and non-insolence,

original: ca issāpahānañca macchariyappahānañca vijjā ca vimutti ca saṅkhatārammaṇo ca vimokkho
analyzed: ca issā apahānañca macchariya ppahānañca vijjā ca vimutti ca saṅkhata ārammaṇaḥ ca vimokkhaḥ
translated: and the abandoning of envy, and the abandoning of avarice, and knowledge, and deliverance, and the conditioned form of deliverance.

original: asaṅkhatārammaṇo ca vimokkho saupādisesā ca nibbānadhātu anupādisesā ca nibbānadhātūti.🔽Ayaṁ vuccati tipukkhalassa ca nayassa aṅkusassa ca nayassa bhūmīti.
analyzed: asaṅkhata ārammaṇaḥ ca vimokkhaḥ sa aupādisesā ca nibbāna dhātu anupādisesā ca nibbāna dhātu uti  ayam vuccati tipukkhalassa ca nayassa aṅkusassa ca nayassa bhūmi iti
translated: and the Unformed Element, and the Extinction Element with Resultant-Form-left, and the Extinction Element without Resultant-Form-left.🔽This is called the plane of the three-cornered and the hook-shaped Guide-Lines.

original: Tenāha “yo akusale samūlehi netī”ti “oloketvā disalocanenā”ti ca.
analyzed: tena āha yaḥ akusale ca
translated: Hence it is said: “He who guides by the roots of the unprofitable” and “Having looked with the eye of knowledge” .

original: Niyuttaṁ nayasamuṭṭhānaṁ.
analyzed: niyuttam naya samuṭṭhāna
translated: The Guide-Line is applied in the Guide-Line’s origin.
